subject: IBM DISTRO_FEATURE ibm-service-account-policy
commitMessage:
IBM DISTRO_FEATURE ibm-service-account-policy

This creates a new DISTRO_FEATURE "ibm-service-account-policy" which
 - Adds an admin account which cannot SSH to the BMC's command shell.
 - Adds a service account which can SSH and has passwordless sudo access.

This feature is applied to witherspoon-tacoma and p10bmc (rainier).

Tested:
  The image behaves as before when the distro feature is not configured.
  When the distro feature is configured:
  The root user has the same access as before.
  The admin user:
   - Is not allowed to access the BMC's command shell.
   - Console login gets: This account is currently not available.
   - SSH login gets: Permission denied, please try again.
   - Redfish and REST API access works with role=Administrator.
  The service user:
   - Console login to the BMC's command shell works.  The home
     directory is /.  Passwordless sudo works.
   - SSH login works and using sudo from a SSH session works.
   - Redfish and REST API access works with role=Administrator.

Change-Id: Icac5ba7f4fa663047709ab55007bbcfec8158f5e
Signed-off-by: Joseph Reynolds <joseph-reynolds@charter.net>

Patch Set 2:

Per discussion in Discord, the new service and admin accounts do not have home directories.  The service account home directory is set to / to allow logins via dropbear SSH server to succeed.
I described additional testing in the commit message.

Patch Set 2:

Every single machine image failed.  I looked at palmetto.  I see testing steps like:
> Step 8/12 : RUN grep -q 1001 /etc/group || groupadd -g 1001 openbmc
> Step 9/12 : RUN grep -q 1000 /etc/passwd || useradd -d /home/openbmc -m -u 1000 -g 1001 openbmc

Note this commit adds new builtin local user accounts.  /etc/passwd contains (excerpt):
> admin:x:1000:1007::/:/sbin/nologin
> service:x:1001:1008::/:/bin/sh

The user and group numbers used for CI conflict with the new builtin accounts.  How to resolve?  Should these new accounts be system accounts (as in `useradd -r`)?  Or should CI select different numbers for this account?

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 4:

A few quick comments:

I'm not sure if this is a result of some evolutionary review cycle, but the long descripton in ibm-enterprise-accounts.inc is, imho, confusing. If this feature is going to be staged, I think we should have every piece self-contained and self-documented in their own commits. If there's a need to document a design/roadmap, I think there are places to do so.

Do we need both an .inc file as well as a Distro feature? Couldn't we make it just a .inc or .bbclass file that once required / inherited, would automatically enable this feature?

I'm not sure how I feel about having password (hashes) as part of the recipe files. I feel like if it's a default / insecure password, it should be in cleartext - for clarity both from a usability point of view, as well as from a security point of view.

Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> A few quick comments:
> 
> I'm not sure if this is a result of some evolutionary review cycle, but the long descripton in ibm-enterprise-accounts.inc is, imho, confusing.

Agree.

> If this feature is going to be staged, I think we should have every piece self-contained and self-documented in their own commits. If there's a need to document a design/roadmap, I think there are places to do so.

Agree.


> Do we need both an .inc file as well as a Distro feature? Couldn't we make it just a .inc or .bbclass file that once required / inherited, would automatically enable this feature?

Agree.  I would just move the include file content inline into the bbappend.

> I'm not sure how I feel about having password (hashes) as part of the recipe files. I feel like if it's a default / insecure password, it should be in cleartext - for clarity both from a usability point of view, as well as from a security point of view.

This makes sense, although I suspect it was copy/pasted from upstream OpenBMC.  Happy to leave this one to Joseph to decide what he thinks makese the most sense.

Patch Set 6:

Warning: You may need to take additional steps to activate this change.  Factory reset (or equivalent) may be needed.

Specifically, this changes the built-in local accounts (data in /etc/passwd, /etc/shadow, /etc/groups, etc.) in the readonly file system.  On IBM systems these are almost always obscured by a readwrite overlayfs to handle changes like new local users, password changes, etc.

If this happens, factory reset makes the changes in this commit appear.  Also, the following workaround was tested and seems to work: SSH to the BMC as the root user, and run the commands: (cd /var/persist/etc && rm -f group group- gshadow gshadow- passwd passwd- shadow shadow-); reboot
This will reset your local accounts to factory defaults.

That's because home is under car and will need to be created in emmc mount or an app.   Similar to etc issues this is not scalable.

@anoo
/var/ and /home/ are empty and populated only at runtime. If a file/directory is needed to be added to the image to be modified at a later time, then /etc/ should be used.

Thanks, I missed that detail.  Do you mean the /home/service directory should be created via a new entry in /etc/tmpfiles.d?

How is /home/root created?  Can I create /home/service the same way?  Please note I don't need to scale this solution because root, admin, and service will be the only pre-configured users, and admin cannot use the shell.

I'd say it makes sense to have the /home/service directory be created the same as the /home/root since it's going to be an account. With that said i'm not really sure how /home/root is created, perhaps by the phosphor-user-manager app? Probably need to ask Ratan.

No mmc init script
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/d79812b8a6676d78fc846c97e670de33e133ad41/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/initrdscripts/phosphor-mmc-init/mmc-init.sh#L59

Oh thanks Milton :) . I take my comments back, I don't think we should be creating extra home directories from the init script, since they're not needed to boot. 
@Joseph, maybe bring this up with the community, to see if it should be some user management app, a stand-alone app, or some other existing one.

If it's just a service home directory I'm ok here.

If we need more it can be a separate service file and script.   We could do meson build to customize a script in phosphor misc
everest ?
Yes, this should to be applied to everest which is not yet defined in meta-ibm/conf/machines.
why admin is not in IPMI group?

The plan for P10 is to disable network IPMI access by default.  See https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/3015

I will add a comment that says network IPMI access is disabled by default, and that the BMC admin can re-enable it.
How does the IPMI know about the encrypted password? IPMI needs the plain text password.

IPMI will not have any passwords; see my answer above.  I'll have to apply the ibm-enterprise-accounts feature (somehow) to clear out this file: https://github.com/openbmc/pam-ipmi/blob/master/ipmi_pass
If IPMI gets enabled by admin then how the IPMI is going to work

I'm not sure what you are asking.  I've edited https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/3015  for clarity.  See step 3 ("change the password").  This invokes the existing pam_ipmisave module which stores the new password into /etc/ipmi_pass when the user is in the "ipmi" group.  See https://github.com/openbmc/pam-ipmi/blob/master/src/pam_ipmisave/pam_ipmisave.c

I think you have got it correctly.

Are we documenting somewhere these three steps apart from the github issue? How to enable the IPMI on the P10 systems?

    1)Use Redfish admin access to re-enable the BMC's network IPMI service (per #612). This starts the network IPMI service daemon.
    2)Use Redfish admin access to authorize local user accounts to use the network IPMI service (per #2577).
    3)Change the password for affected local user accounts via Redfish or Web UI (or have each user do that). It is necessary for the IPMI implementation to handle the new password before it can allow access.

For IBM P10?  I've created an item inside IBM to track this and to raise the visibility of this change to our service organization, information developers (writers), testers, manufacturing tools, etc.  I've specifically pinged our IBM Knowledge Center writer.
What is the decrypted password of this encrypted string?
This is the traditional OpenBMC default password hash which represents the password: 0penBmc

I don't think the service account ought to be allowed be able to use network IPMI.  Ever.  There are both the traditional security risks of using IPMI and technical difficulties due to the pending-ACF design.  I'll remove this group.
Enterprise is a marketing buzzword and doesn't convey any information.  Consider avoiding it.
Thanks.  This is for IBM POWER systems which use the "service" account.
Should we let those considering making use of your work decide whether or not it is appropriate?
Yep.  I'll clarify the purpose of this feature and drop this sentence.
ibm-account-policy?  just a suggestion, as a way to avoid "enterprise" if you want to follow that earlier suggestion.
How about "ibm-service-account-policy"?  It's good!

Agree with Klaus - the code is not the place to document these things.  As a maintainer I assume every patch I get is the last one I will receive from a contributor and why each patch must be self contained.
I'll remove this.
is it?  On line 87 you have += which should append your extra arguments not replace the existing ones?
I waffled on this.  The next patchset will need to override the defaults in meta-phosphor, for example, to undo the root user password.  I'll fix in this patchset.

this is a bit verbose since its only used in the obmc-phosphor-image recipe.  is there a reason to be explicit here?  These kinds of package name based overrides make sense when you specify EXTRA_USERS_PARAMS from the global configuration but we aren't doing that.  I think you can safely just:

 EXTRA_USERS_PARAMS += ""
Thanks for explaining that.  I will remove this piece.
no dead code, todos, or commented out code please.
I had intended to indicate this feature was considered and not used.  Will remove.

Installing sudo was conditional on the distro feature, so these modifications to it should be as well:

 PACKAGECONFIG_append = " ${@bb.utils.contains('DISTRO_FEATURES', 'ibm-enterprise-accounts', 'pam-wheel', '', d)}"

 do_install_append() 
     if [${@bb.utils.contains('DISTRO_FEATURES', 'ibm-enterprise-accounts', '1', '0', d)} = "0"]; then
         # Allow members of the 'wheel' group to use passwordless sudo
         sed -i 's/# \(%wheel ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL\)/\1/' ${D}${sysconfdir}/sudoers
     fi
 }

I disagree.  I think we'll want to use these for all IBM use cases.
Maybe I should propose a patch to the OpenBMC project?

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/42429
was created for this purpose.  See the OpenBMC security working group, minutes from 2020-11-11.
Added to the upcoming agenda to discuss https://docs.google.com/document/d/1b7x9BaxsfcukQDqbvZsU2ehMq4xoJRQvLxxsDUWmAOI
UPDATE: This was abandoned because it is an IBM-specific use case.
I think the IBM use case is for authorized BMC command shell users to have passwordless sudo access.
please just move the content inline
Will do.
Oops.  I'll remove this line for now.  I will have to change this to override project defaults when I remove the root user login capability.
